questions.question: Computer security involves protecting hardware, software, and data.
The C-I-A Triad includes Confidentiality, Integrity, and Authentication.
A vulnerability is a weakness in the security system that might be exploited to cause loss or harm.
A threat is always caused by human actions.
Nonrepudiation ensures that a party cannot deny the authenticity of their signature or message.
Access control policies only consider who can access an object, not how.
An Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) is typically well-financed and patient.
Interruption in security terms means that an asset has been modified by an unauthorized party.
Encryption can be used to ensure both confidentiality and integrity of data.
Weak encryption is always better than no encryption at all.
Software controls must be carefully designed to balance ease of use and security.
Hardware controls are less effective than software controls in providing computer security.
Physical controls, such as locks and guards, are part of a comprehensive security strategy.
The Principle of Effectiveness states that controls must be complex to be effective.
Overlapping controls can address a single vulnerability from multiple angles.
The Principle of Weakest Link states that security is only as strong as its strongest link.
Periodic review of controls is necessary because attackers continuously evolve their methods.
Confidentiality, integrity, and availability are always mutually exclusive.
Detection is one of the goals of security, aiming to identify attackers' violations of security policies.
Trust is not a factor in the effectiveness of security mechanisms.

Multi-factor authentication (MFA) requires at least two different authentication factors.
Biometric authentication is considered the least secure form of authentication.
A dictionary attack is a common method used to exploit 'something you know' authentication factors.
Location factors are always considered a part of authentication rather than authorization.
Behavioral biometrics can continuously authenticate a user based on their interaction patterns.
A security token is always a hardware device and cannot be software-based.
Federated Identity Management (FIM) allows users to access multiple systems across different organizations using a single set of credentials.
Single Sign-On (SSO) and Federated Identity Management (FIM) are the same concepts.
A reference monitor must mediate all access requests between subjects and objects in a system.
Access control lists (ACLs) are less granular than access control matrices.
Symmetric encryption uses the same key for both encryption and decryption.
Asymmetric encryption is faster than symmetric encryption for large amounts of data.
DES (Data Encryption Standard) uses a 56-bit key, which is considered weak by modern standards.
AES (Advanced Encryption Standard) is less secure than DES due to its smaller key size.
Public key cryptography is commonly used for key exchange and digital signatures.
A man-in-the-middle attack cannot occur during a key exchange process.
Error-detecting codes like CRC (Cyclic Redundancy Check) can detect modifications in data.
One-way hash functions are reversible, meaning the original data can be retrieved from the hash.
Digital certificates bind a public key to an identity and are signed by a Certificate Authority (CA).
A Certificate Authority (CA) does not need to verify identities before issuing certificates.

Programs are represented as strings of 0s and 1s, which correspond to elementary machine commands.
The Intel 32- and 64-bit instruction set has over 100 basic primitives.
Buffer overflows occur when data is written beyond the allocated memory space.
A buffer overflow can only affect the user's data and never the system's code.
The stack in memory uses a Last-In, First-Out (LIFO) method to manage data.
Heap overflows are more common than stack overflows in buffer overflow attacks.
Malware can include viruses, worms, and Trojan horses.
A worm is a type of malware that requires user interaction to spread.
SQL injection attacks exploit vulnerabilities in database queries.
Cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks only affect the server-side of web applications.
Input fuzzing is a software testing technique that uses randomly generated data to test program robustness.

A reference monitor mediates all access requests between subjects and objects in a system.
Access control lists (ACLs) are less secure than access control matrices.

Input fuzzing is only useful for security testing and not for reliability testing.
